column2: (singing, duh) Morning\xc2\x92s here! Sunshine is here! The sky\nis clear, the morning\xc2\x92s here! The morning\xc2\x92s here!'
HEY!! Do you have to do that? It\xc2\x92s Saturday!'
Oh come on! Morning\xc2\x92s here! (Starts singing)\nMorning\xc2\x92s here! The morning is here! Sunshine is here!'
I hate this apartment! I hate the color of these walls! I hate\nthe fact that this place still smells like bird! I hate that singing guy!'
Are you kidding? I love that guy! (Starts singing) Morning\xc2\x92s here!\nMorning is here\xc2\x97'
Stop it! I will kill you. I hate the fact that my room is so small.'
Hey, I have all the space I need. Just do what I did.'
Monica, you don\xc2\x92t even have a bed, you sleep in a ball on the\nfloor!'
Y\xc2\x92know what? I am really tired of your bellyaching! Okay,\nI-I worked really hard at making this a nice place for us to live!'
I\xc2\x92m sorry. I\xc2\x92m so sorry.'
Okay.'
See, this is a great apartment.'
Shut up! This place is a hole!'
Oh, blimey, I still can\xc2\x92t believe you\xc2\x92ve got an earring!'
Huh? I know, I know. Who am I? David Bowe? (Shakes his head around,\npretending like he\xc2\x92s jamming.)'
He does that?!'
Uh, I don\xc2\x92t know, whatever.'
I think it makes you look really dangerous.'

Oh, I know. Y\xc2\x92know what, I never would\xc2\x92ve gotten this if it
weren\xc2\x92t for you. No really, when I\xc2\x92m with you I\xc2\x92m-I\xc2\x92m like this whole
other guy, I love that guy! I mean, I love you too, a lot, but that guy! I-I love
that guy!'
I love both of you!'
Yeah?'
I wish I didn\xc2\x92t have to go.'
Then don\xc2\x92t. Stay here. Just don\xc2\x92t go so soon to London, just one\nmore day.'
Ohh, Ross, please!'
One more day, seriously/'
Don\xc2\x92t do this to me, again. You\xc2\x92d know I\xc2\x92d stay here in a\nminute, but I\xc2\x92d really miss so much work, they\xc2\x92ll fire me.'
So, then you can stay as long as you want.'
I wish I could.'
Oh no. Don\xc2\x92t, don\xc2\x92t, don\xc2\x92t start packing. Come on! (She\nputs some clothes into her bag, and Ross throws them out.)'
I don\xc2\x92t think you understand packing. Look, I just don\xc2\x92t want\nto leave it to the last minute. Last time I left in such a rush, I left my knickers here.'
Yeah, I know, I uh, I tried them on.'
You didn\xc2\x92t!'
No. No, I didn\xc2\x92t. I didn\xc2\x92t want to be that guy.'
(entering, wearing Santa pants) Hello!'
Ho! Ho! Ho!'
Excuse me.'
Your pants!'
Oh, yeah! You like \xc2\x91em? I just, I went to a used clothes store and\ngot a bunch of maternity stuff. These are sooo comfortable!'
Uhh, Pheebs, those are uh, those are Santa pants.'
What?'
Santa pants. (Phoebe still doesn\xc2\x92t get it.) Santa Claus\xc2\x92s\npants.'

Nuh-uh! They\xc2\x92re maternity pants. They even came with a list of baby
names. (Pulls out a sheet of paper which lists who\xc2\x92s been naughty and who\xc2\x92s been
nice.) See, these names are good, and these names are bad. (Finally, she figures it out.)
Ohh.'
(entering) Hey!'
(entering) Hey!'
So\xc2\x97Hey, Pheebs! So, how are the elves?'
I don\xc2\x92t know! How are the-the-the-the, y\xc2\x92know\xc2\x97You\xc2\x92re\nclothes aren\xc2\x92t funny.'
Hey, guys, what-what should I wear to a Knicks game?'
Uhh, a T-shirt that says, "I don\xc2\x92t belong here."'
You have Knicks tickets?'
Yeah, my mom got my dad\xc2\x92s season tickets in the divorce, so she\njust gave them to me.'
Yeah, apparently, they\xc2\x92re pretty good seats.'
Yeah.'
(examining the tickets) Oh my God! Those are almost right on the floor!'
Do you guys want these?'
Yeah we do!'
Ohh, well you got \xc2\x91em.'
Just give us our apartment back!'
Boy! I didn\xc2\x92t see that coming!'
Are you serious?'
Oh, come on! We know what these are worth.'
Yeah, what, do you think we\xc2\x92re stupid?'
You\xc2\x92re not stupid. You\xc2\x92re meaner than I thought.'
What do you say?'
Forget it! Okay, I\xc2\x92m not giving up my bachelor pad for some\nbasketball seats!'
You\xc2\x92re bachelor pad?!'
Have you even had a girl up here?'
No. But uh, Joey has, and I usually talk to them in the morning time.'
Yeah, you do!'
Come on!'
(ignoring him) Yes, Gunther, can I get two cups of chino, please?'
Good one.'
Come on, season tickets! Season tickets, do you know what that means?'
Forget it! Okay, I\xc2\x92m not giving up the apartment.'

Oh come\xc2\x97look, when I was a kid my dad\xc2\x92s company gave season\ntickets to the number one salesman every year, all right? My dad never won! Of\ncourse, he wasn\xc2\x92t in the sales division, but still, I never ever, ever forgot that!'
(entering) Hey, guys! (They both notice his new little friend)'
Hey!'
Oh my God!'
We don\xc2\x92t make enough fun of you already?'
Oh yeah, Emily convinced me to do it.'
You do know that Wham broke up?'
I like it, and Emily likes it, and that\xc2\x92s what counts. So uh, how are\nyou guys doing?'
Oh-no, don\xc2\x92t try and talk all normal with that thing in your ear.'
Where is Emily?'
Ugh, she\xc2\x92s saying good-bye to her uncle.'
Man, didn\xc2\x92t she like just get here?'
Yeah!! Yeah!'
Easy tiger.'

I just, I hate this so much! I mean, every time I go pick her up at the\nairport, it\xc2\x92s-it\xc2\x92s so great. But at the same time I\xc2\x92m thinking, "Well,\nI\xc2\x92m gonna be right back there in a couple of days, dropping her off."'
So what are you going to do?'
Nothing! There\xc2\x92s nothing to do! I mean, she lives there, I live here.\nI mean, she-she\xc2\x92d have to uh, move here. She should move here!'
What?'
I could ask her to live with me!'
Are you serious?'
I mean, why not! I mean, I mean why not?!'
Because you\xc2\x92ve only known her for six weeks! Okay, I\xc2\x92ve got\na carton of milk in my fridge I\xc2\x92ve had a longer relationship with!'
Look guys, when I\xc2\x92m with her it\xc2\x92s-it\xc2\x92s-it\xc2\x92s like she\nbrings this-this-this great side out of me. I mean I-I-I love her, y\xc2\x92know?'
And I love the milk! But, I\xc2\x92m not gonna some British girl to move\nin with me! (Realizes that made no sense.) Joey, you say things now.'
All right look, Ross, he\xc2\x92s right. Emily\xc2\x92s great, she\xc2\x92s\ngreat! But this way too soon, you\xc2\x92re only gonna scare her!'
I don\xc2\x92t want to do that.'
No! You don\xc2\x92t want to wreck it, you don\xc2\x92t want to go to fast!'
Yeah, no, you\xc2\x92re right, I know, you\xc2\x92re right, I\xc2\x92m not,\nI\xc2\x92m not gonna do it. All right, thanks guys. (Gets up to leave.)'
Okay, no problem, just remember to wake us up before you go-go.'
That\xc2\x92s too hard. Too hard!'
(entering with Rachel) All right boys, last chance for the tickets!'
Or I\xc2\x92ll give them to my new boyfriend, Joshua.'
No thank you.'
Wait-wait-wait-wait! (To Chandler) Come on! Come on, let\xc2\x92s trade! The\ntiming\xc2\x92s perfect, I just clogged the toilet! '
Look, I want those basketball seats as much as you do! Okay, but we\ncan\xc2\x92t leave in the small apartment after we\xc2\x92ve lived here! Didn\xc2\x92t you ever\nread Flowers for Algernon?'
Yes! Didn\xc2\x92t you ever read Sports Illustrated?! No! I\ndidn\xc2\x92t read yours! But come on, we can go to the game tonight!'
Look, the only way I will even consider this is if they offer a lot\nmore than just season seats.'
It\xc2\x92s the Knicks!'
Screw the Knicks!'
Whoa!'
I didn\xc2\x92t mean that. I just meant that the apartment is worth so\nmuch more.'
Huh.'
And the Knicks rule all.'
Yeah, the Knicks rule all!'
Hey, so? Are you gonna do it?'
No. No. We\xc2\x92re not gonna do that, y\xc2\x92know why? Because its not\nan even trade.'
All right, okay, look, what if you could keep the apartment and get the\ntickets?'
Done!'
Let me finish. '
Oh. '
I\xc2\x92m talking about a bet, winner takes all.'
Ooh, we could end up with nothing.'
Or you could end up with everything.'
Ooh, I like that.'
All right, so what do you say?'
No!'
Oh, just do it!!'
Op, op, I\xc2\x92m convinced!'
Come on man, you know I\xc2\x92d do it for you! Because, you\xc2\x92re my best\nfriend.'
All right, but you can\xc2\x92t use that again for a whole year.\nI\xc2\x92m in.'
All right!'
Ooh, this is so exciting! Ooh, God, what are you going to bet?'
Oh, okay, well, I think we should let Phoebe decide, because she\xc2\x92s\nthe only who\xc2\x92s impartial, and she\xc2\x92s so pretty.'
Okay. Umm, ooh, ooh\xc2\x97oh, I have a game!'
Okay! '
Okay!'
This is great!'
What\xc2\x92s the game?! What\xc2\x92s the game?!'
Oh, well, it doesn\xc2\x92t have a name\xc2\x97oh, okay, Phoebeball! No, it\ndoesn\xc2\x92t have a name. Umm, okay, Monica, what is your favourite thing about trees?'
They\xc2\x92re green?'
Good! Good! Five points!'
All right, Joey, same question.'
Uhh, they\xc2\x92re tall.'
Ooh, three points. Both fine answers, but we were looking for leafy,\nleafy.'
That\xc2\x92s not even a game!'
What? Shut up! We\xc2\x92re winning!'
You wanna finish this right now? All right, we get a deck of cards, high\ncard wins. What do you say?'
Fine, let\xc2\x92s do it.'
Oh, I have cards!'
Oh.'
Oh, good.'
Yeah! Here! (She grabs a deck out of her purse) Oh no, these are the\ntrick deck. Okay. Here yes. Okay.'
Okay, you guys uh, you guys pick first'
Okay.'
Okay. (She picks a card.) Four.'
That\xc2\x92s a low one!'
Yeah! Okay. (Joey picks a card.) Phoebe, you look, I can\xc2\x92t.'
What make you think I can?! (Shields her eyes from it.)'
Okay. Okay. (He looks at the card.) Ace!'
Why are you screaming and hugging?'
Because we won our apartment back!'
What? Ace is high! Jack, queen, king, ace!'
No! Ace is low! Ace, two, three, four!'
I don\xc2\x92t know. Ooh! Ooh! Look it! (She fans out the trick deck.)\nAh-ha!'
All right, cut, let\xc2\x92s pick again, pick again.'
Okay.'
Come on apartment! Come on apartment! (Picks a card.) Oh! I know queen\nis high!'
Uh-huh, not as high as\xc2\x85(picks a card) It worked! King!'
Yeah baby!'
But, we pick again! We pick again!'
Why?!'
I don\xc2\x92t know!'
Tickets please! (Rachel hands over the tickets) That\xc2\x92s courtside\nbaby!'
Seriously, good game though. Good game. (He tries to congratulate them,\nbut they pull away.) (To Chandler) What are they so mad about? They get the apartment\nback!'
No they didn\xc2\x92t!'
Hey!'
I packed while you were gone. I left some knickers under your pillow.'
(laughs) Move in with me.'
What?!'
Don\xc2\x92t be scared, I-I know it sounds crazy and-and people will say\nit\xc2\x92s too soon, but just-just think, think how great it will be.'
Ohh, no. Ugh. Oh, leaving London, my whole family lives there.'
I know.'
My job!'
Well, so, you-you\xc2\x92ll get a job here! I mean, I\xc2\x92m always hearing\nabout uh, them foreigners coming in here and stealing American jobs; that could be you!'
Yeah, but it-it-it\xc2\x92s my whole life\xc2\x97you come to England.'
No, I can\xc2\x92t. I would, I really would, but my son is here; I\ncan\xc2\x92t leave him. Isn\xc2\x92t\xc2\x97you don\xc2\x92t think there\xc2\x92s any way?'
Ohh, I don\xc2\x92t think so. I mean it would be different if it was way\ninto the future \xc2\x96and-and-and we were getting married or something.'
What?'
Oh no, no, right I shouldn\xc2\x92t have said married. Uh, please\ndon\xc2\x92t go freaky on me. I didn\xc2\x92t mean it. Well, I didn\xc2\x92t say it; I take it\nback!'
No, no, don\xc2\x92t. Why don\xc2\x92t we?'
Why don\xc2\x92t we what?'
Get married.'
You are mad!'

No! No! I\xc2\x92m not! It\xc2\x92s-it\xc2\x92s-it\xc2\x92s perfect! I mean\nit\xc2\x92s better than you just-just moving here, \xc2\x91cause it\xc2\x92s us together\nforever, and that\xc2\x92s-that\xc2\x92s what I want.'
We\xc2\x92ve only known each other for six weeks!'

Yeah, I know, so what? I mean, who\xc2\x92s-who\xc2\x92s to say? Does that me
we-we can\xc2\x92t do it? Look, huh, I was with Carol for four years before we got married
and I wound up divorced from a pregnant lesbian. I mean, this, this makes sense for us.
Come on! I mean, on our first date we ended up spending the whole weekend in Vermont! I
mean, last night I got my ear pierced! Me! This feels right. Doesn\xc2\x92t it?'
My parents are going to be really mad.'
Is that\xc2\x97are you saying yes? Is that yes?'
Yes.'
Yes!'
Yes! We\xc2\x92re getting married?!'
Oh my God! '
Yes!'
We\xc2\x92re getting married!'
Come here, come here. Uh, (He takes the earring out.) ow! Emily, will you\nmarry me?'
Yes.'
Ohh, it\xc2\x92s a bit small.'
Damn! I thought that was going to be romantic as hell!'
It was.'
Those were like the best seats ever.'
Oh yeah. Hey! Should we give these shirts to the girls? Y\xc2\x92know, kinda\nlike a peace offering.'
Oh yeah, that\xc2\x92s very nice. Plus, y\xc2\x92know they were free and\nthey\xc2\x92re too small.'
Oh. Oh, God! (He starts running around like a chicken with his head\ncut off.)'
Hey, want a beer? (Hands him a beer and sits down in one of the chairs.)\n(Jumping up.) WHOA!!!!'
I KNOW!!!'
Open up! Open up! Open up!'
We\xc2\x92ll discuss it, in the morning! (Slams the door shut.)'
What the hell is going on?!'
We took our apartment back!! (Slams the door shut.)'
(opening the door) I had nothing to do with it. (Closes the door.)\n(Opens the door.) Okay, it was my idea, but I don\xc2\x92t feel good about it.'
We are switching back, right now!'
No, we\xc2\x92re not! We\xc2\x92re not leaving!'
Well, you\xc2\x92re gonna have to leave sometime, because you both have\njobs, and as soon as you do, we\xc2\x92re switching it back! There\xc2\x92s nothing you can do\nto stop us! Right, Joe?'
I don\xc2\x92t know.'
What?'
I don\xc2\x92t want to move again! '

I don\xc2\x92t care, this is our apartment! And they stole\xc2\x97you\nstole it\xc2\x97our apartment, and we won that apartment fair and square, twice! And I am\ngetting it back right now. I\xc2\x92m getting back right now!'
All right. We figured you might respond this way, so we have a backup\noffer.'
Oh no-no-no, no more offers. You can\xc2\x92t offer anything to us!'
Let us keep the apartment and\xc2\x85'
As a thank you, Rachel and I will kiss for one minute.'
Totally worth it!'
That was one good minute!'
Good night.'
Good night.'
Men are such idiots.'
Yeah! Can you believe that something that stupid actually got us our\napartment back?'
That\xc2\x92s so funny to think if you\xc2\x92d just done that right after\nthe last contest, no one would have had to move at all.'
Yeah, let-let-let\xc2\x92s pretend that\xc2\x92s not true.'
Yeah.'
Okay, scarf\xc2\x92s done. (It\xc2\x92s not really a scarf, it\xc2\x92s just a\nbunch of yarn that Phoebe has tied together. Just then, Ross and Emily enter dragging with\nthem Joey and Chandler.)'
Come on! Come on. Come on.'
Okay!'
Hey!'
Hey!'
What-what\xc2\x92s going on?'
Ross has some big thing to tell everyone.'
Uhh, okay, it\xc2\x92s uh, Emily and I, we decided to uh, to get married.'
What? Oh, are you pregnant too?!'
Umm, no.'
When, when did\xc2\x97how, how did you\xc2\x85'
We, we just decided to uh, to go for it.'
I mean, we know it\xc2\x92s a bit hasty but, uh, it just feels so right,\nso\xc2\x85'
(turning around.) Umm, uh, I was just telling the guys\xc2\x85'
Yeah, I-I heard. (Pause, everyone looks at each other, waiting for\nRachel\xc2\x92s reaction.) I think it\xc2\x92s great! (Hugs Ross.) Ohh, I\xc2\x92m so happy for\nyou!'
Oh, well, that\xc2\x92s great!'
Yeah! Yeah!'
(to Ross) I can\xc2\x92t believe you\xc2\x92re getting married! '
Yeah. (They hug again.)'
Monica and Rachel made out. (Giggles like a schoolboy and Monica glares at\nhim.)'
(singing) Morning\xc2\x92s here! The morning\xc2\x92s here! '
Hey! You\xc2\x92re back!'
Hey! (Singing) Get into gear!'
(singing) Breakfast is near!'
I\xc2\x92ll see you tomorrow morning!'
(happily) Okay!'
